Article Title: Jio Payments Bank wins contract for next-gen highway tolling system
Article Text: Jio Payments Bank has secured a contract to implement advanced Multi-Lane Free Flow (MLFF) toll collection systems at two toll plazas on the Gurugram-Jaipur highway, marking its entry into India's next-generation tolling infrastructure.The digital payments bank will deploy FASTag Automatic Number Plate Recognition-based MLFF technology at the Shahjahanpur and Manoharpura toll plazas. This system allows vehicles to pass through toll points without slowing down or stopping, using a combination of radio-frequency identification, ANPR, and satellite navigation technologies.The contract, awarded by Indian Highways Management Company Limited (IHMCL), is part of India's pilot MLFF project aimed at creating barrier-free movement on national highways. Of the five MLFF bids awarded so far, Jio Payments Bank has won two, demonstrating strong competitiveness in the emerging sector.This milestone builds on the company's existing toll operations, which began in July 2025. Jio Payments Bank currently manages toll collection at 11 plazas across various highway stretches as an acquirer bank. The MLFF expansion positions the payments bank to play a larger role in India's infrastructure-linked digital payments ecosystem."Our expansion into the tolling ecosystem is a natural progression of our mission to digitise everyday payments and build smart financial infrastructure at scale," said Vinod Easwaran, Managing Director and CEO of Jio Payments Bank.The company plans to leverage synergies with Jio Platforms' digital capabilities for its toll management operations, aligning with India's rapid infrastructure development and digitalization efforts.Jio Payments Bank is a subsidiary of Jio Financial Services Limited, which operates multiple financial services through the JioFinance app.
Article Summary: Jio Payments Bank has secured a contract to implement advanced Multi-Lane Free Flow (MLFF) toll collection systems at two toll plazas on the Gurugram-Jaipur highway. The contract is part of India's pilot MLFF project aimed at creating barrier-free movement on national highways.

The ministry cited ‚Äúrecent and acute signals of serious governance shortcomings‚Äù at Nexperia, warning that these posed a threat to Dutch and European technological capabilities. Nijmegen-headquartered Nexperia Nexperia is one of the world's largest makers of simple computer chips such as diodes and transistors, though it also develops more advanced technologies such as "wide gap" semiconductors used in electrical settings and useful for electric cars, chargers and AI data centres.‚ÄúLosing these capabilities could pose a risk to Dutch and European economic security,‚Äù the statement read, highlighting the automotive sector‚Äôs vulnerability. The intervention, described as ‚Äúhighly exceptional,‚Äù was enacted in September to prevent potential disruptions in chip supply during emergencies.The move comes amid heightened U.S.-China trade tensions, with the US President Donald Trump recently threatening 100% tariffs on Chinese exports.While the Dutch Economic Affairs Ministry denied U.S. involvement, calling the timing ‚Äúpurely coincidental,‚Äù the decision aligns with broader US-Netherlands cooperation on chip industry export controls. The move underscores Beijing's growing assertiveness in controlling critical resources as geopolitical dynamics shift.
